sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Bhutan is a small landlocked kingdom in the Eastern Himalayas, known for its stunning landscapes, Buddhist traditions, and unique philosophy of Gross National Happiness.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Thimphu is the capital and largest city of Bhutan, serving as its political, cultural, and economic center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Bhutanese ngultrum (BTN), pegged to the Indian rupee.

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Dzongkha, though several regional languages are spoken across the country.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include ema datshi (chilies with cheese), momo (dumplings), red rice, and suja (butter tea).

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Bhutan is a mountainous country in the Himalayas, with lush valleys, rivers, and forests. It is known for its biodiversity and conservation efforts.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Bhutanese culture is deeply rooted in Vajrayana Buddhism, with vibrant festivals (tsechus), traditional dress (gho and kira), and strong community values.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism highlights include the Tiger’s Nest Monastery (Paro Taktsang), Punakha Dzong, Dochula Pass, and the pristine Himalayan landscapes.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Bhutan measures progress through Gross National Happiness (GNH), prioritizing well-being and environmental sustainability over GDP.

history.event: Buddhism was introduced to Bhutan, with Tibetan influence shaping its spiritual and cultural foundations.
Ngawang Namgyal, a Tibetan lama, unified Bhutan and established the dual system of governance combining secular and religious authority.
Bhutan defended its independence against invasions from Tibet and the Mughal Empire.
The Treaty of Sinchula was signed with British India, ceding some territories but maintaining Bhutan’s sovereignty.
Ugyen Wangchuck was crowned the first King of Bhutan, establishing the hereditary monarchy.
Bhutan signed the Treaty of Friendship with India, ensuring mutual respect and cooperation.
Bhutan joined the United Nations, gaining international recognition as a sovereign state.
Bhutan transitioned to a constitutional monarchy and held its first democratic elections.
